text: The University of Cambridge was founded in 1209 and is one of the oldest universities in the world.
Cambridge is made up of 31 autonomous colleges, each with its own traditions, history, and architecture.
Students at Cambridge are members of both a College and a University Faculty or Department.
Punting on the River Cam is one of the most popular leisure activities in Cambridge.
King's College Chapel is famous for its Gothic architecture and world-renowned choir.
The May Bumps and Lent Bumps are traditional rowing races held on the River Cam between the colleges.
The Mathematical Bridge at Queens’ College is a wooden bridge built in 1749, often mistakenly said to hold itself together without bolts.
The University Library is one of the six legal deposit libraries in the UK, entitled to receive a copy of every book published in the country.
The Cambridge University Botanic Garden spans 40 acres and houses more than 8,000 species of plants.
Trinity College was founded by Henry VIII in 1546 and is the largest of all the Cambridge colleges.
The college formal hall is a traditional three-course dinner where students and fellows dine in formal attire.
The term 'supervision' refers to the small-group teaching system at Cambridge, often involving one or two students and a supervisor.
Cambridge students refer to semesters as 'Michaelmas', 'Lent', and 'Easter' terms.
The May Ball is an annual formal celebration held at the end of the academic year by many colleges.
The 'Backs' refers to the picturesque area behind several Cambridge colleges where their gardens back onto the River Cam.
Cambridge alumni include Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Alan Turing, and Stephen Hawking.
The University of Cambridge Press, founded in 1534, is the oldest publishing house in the world.
Trinity College’s Great Court hosts the Great Court Run, where students attempt to run around the court before the clock finishes striking 12.
The University of Cambridge has produced over 120 Nobel Prize winners across various disciplines.
The Cambridge Union Society, founded in 1815, is the world's oldest debating society.
The Cavendish Laboratory, established in 1874, is known for major physics discoveries including the electron and the structure of DNA.
The Fitzwilliam Museum houses world-class collections of art and antiquities and is free to visit.
Corpus Christi College is known for the Corpus Clock, also called the Chronophage, which features a large golden grasshopper sculpture.
Pembroke College was the first college in Cambridge to have its own chapel, designed by Sir Christopher Wren.
Clare College is the second-oldest college in Cambridge, founded in 1326.
King’s Parade is a central street in Cambridge lined with shops, cafés, and historic buildings.
Students traditionally wear academic gowns for formal events and examinations.
College porters are staff who help manage security, maintenance, and student welfare within each college.
Cambridge has its own unique slang: 'bop' means a college party, and 'plodge' refers to the porter’s lodge.
The 'Cambridge Blue' is the official sporting colour awarded to athletes representing the university in varsity competitions against Oxford.
The Boat Race between Oxford and Cambridge takes place annually on the River Thames in London.
The city of Cambridge is approximately 60 miles north of London and has a population of around 130,000.
The Centre for Mathematical Sciences (CMS) is home to the Faculty of Mathematics and the Isaac Newton Institute.
Students often travel around Cambridge by bicycle; the city is known for being very bike-friendly.
Many colleges require students to attend 'matriculation', an official ceremony marking the start of their studies.
College libraries, often open late, are key study spaces for students during exam term.
Cambridge has a collegiate dining tradition where students dine at long wooden tables under candlelight.
The university has eight museums and collections open to the public, including the Sedgwick Museum of Earth Sciences.
The Cambridge Science Festival and Festival of Ideas are annual events that celebrate research and public engagement.
Peterhouse, founded in 1284, is the oldest college in Cambridge.
The Senate House, completed in 1730, is where degree ceremonies are traditionally held.
Cambridge students often describe the intense 8-week terms as a 'sprint, not a marathon'.
The University’s motto is 'Hinc lucem et pocula sacra', meaning 'From here, light and sacred draughts'.
Addenbrooke’s Hospital is part of the Cambridge Biomedical Campus, one of Europe’s largest centres of medical research.
The Cambridge Enterprise office supports university members in commercialising their research.
The Cambridge English exams, including IELTS, are developed by the University of Cambridge.
The Cambridge University Students’ Union (CUSU) represents the interests of all students across the university.
Jesus Green and Parker’s Piece are popular open spaces for picnics, football, and social gatherings.
The University’s colleges vary greatly in size, with some housing fewer than 300 students and others over 1,000.
Cambridge has inspired countless literary works and films, including 'The Theory of Everything' about Stephen Hawking.
